poem:
"Cease Drill to Cherish"

In Biscathorpe, a battle begins,
Campaigners rally 'gainst oil-tin sins.
In the Wolds where green beauty thrives,
A field marked for oil's lethal knives.
Wildlife whispers, nature pleads,
Respect the land, leave the seeds.
A reprieve won, the plans oppress,
The rural treasure in soft caress.
Silent challenge, quiet and bold,
For the love of Lincolnshire Wolds.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Campaigners get go-ahead to challenge plans for oilfield in Lincolnshire Wolds Campaigners have been given permission to challenge plans for a new oilfield in an area of outstanding natural beauty – which they say threatens one of England’s “hidden rural treasures”. The proposed oil-drilling operation is in Biscathorpe in the Lincolnshire Wolds, an important habitat for nature and wildlife that has been officially designated an area of outstanding natural beauty (AONB). The plans were rejected". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
